results.title: A Bird's eye view
results.creator_credit: Roger Whittaker, ABC-TV (Australia) and Roger Whittaker Films
results.brief_description: The Kookaburra and the Magpie are two of our national icons. Everyone recognises the Kookaburra by its laugh, but in ‘Kookaburra’, its fascinating social system is revealed as well as its expert fishing abilities. The Magpie has a beautiful call but can be aggressive and territorial. The complete life cycle of this common but fascinating bird is explored in ‘Magpie’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Whittaker, ABC-TV (Australia) and Roger Whittaker Films

results.title: 7 Days in September
results.creator_credit: Steven Rosenbaum and Broadcast News Networks
results.brief_description: This moving, if rudimentarily filmed documentary, is a collective account of ‘September 11, 2001’ and that day’s impact on a variety of New Yorkers. The filmmakers utilise an array of original footage shot over that week by professionals and by amateurs; they also interview an array of people who lived in New York at the time who describe their own responses and the unusual occurrences witnessed. The narrative focuses on the feel in New York over the week: the mood on the street, impromptu prayer sessions that were conducted, for example, as well as debates that raged between strangers; the clean up effort and the way that people pulled together, helping each other, making donations, giving blood, and providing emotional support. Whilst in no way an analysis of the calamity, the filmmakers eloquently capture the small stories. The work in a minor way, also addresses the role and the dilemma of any documentary filmmaker caught up in a tragedy - to film or not to film and at what stage does observation of a grand-scale catastrophe cross over into exploitation and opportunism.

results.title: A Better way
results.brief_description: In order to keep Canada’s vast quantities of mail moving, Canada Post dug around for a suitable solution. They came up with MAPP (Major Area Postal Plant), an ingenious, highly complex, streamlined system that relies on the postal code for efficient operation. The postal code relies on you and me, the mailing public, for inclusion in the address. The film tells what happens when a piece of mail is set on its course. No other credits available.

results.title: 64,000,000 years ago
results.creator_credit: Bill Maylone, George Johnson, John Taylor, National Film Board of Canada and Pacific Films
results.brief_description: This short animated film for children looks at the last of the great dinosaurs to stalk the central plains of North America. Lifelike models of ornithomimus, edmontosaur, and triceratops recreate the late Cretaceous period, offering a view of how our world may have looked 64,000,000 years ago. The soundtrack is filled with growls and roars with the occassional voice-over narration.

results.title: 60 cycles [French version]
results.creator_credit: Jean-Claude Labrecque and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The 11th. St Laurent long distance cycling race with participants from 13 countries covers 1500 miles of the Quebec countryside in 12 days. From a distance, the cyclists are a moving colour frieze against the picturesque landscape; closer we see the taut faces and straining limbs of the competitiors above the bright circle of their machines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean-Claude Labrecque and National Film Board of Canada

results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Produced for the Bank of NSW as part of its 150th anniversary celebrations. Shows the scenery and colourful life of Fiji and the activities of an officer providing banking services.

results.title: A Bandit in Baling = Ba Ling Qie Zei
results.creator_credit: Wang Yi, Sun Yan and Pearl River Film Studio
results.brief_description:
In the late Qing Dynasty, veteran of the Taiping Rebellion, Liu Hedong runs a small sculpture shop with his daughter, Liu Yizhi at Baling. After the Taiping Rebellion failed, Liu only wants to have a quiet life with his daughter in the small town. However, a rich businessman, Mr. Yang came one day and asked Liu to duplicate a treasure of the town—Fan Zhongyan’s Travel Notes on Yueyang Building carved on twelve big wood pieces, placed in the Yueyang Building. Liu did that for Mr. Yang but later became suspicious of Yang’s purpose. He rushed to the Yueyang Building with his daughter only to find the authentic woodcarvings had been replaced by his work and the guard of the Building was killed. Liu reported this to the newly-appointed county magistrate, who ordered that all must be done to catch the thief. Liu, a kung-fu master himself, also tried to find the thief, but in the meantime, a couple of young ladies have been killed by darts that belonged to Liu. Liu was imprisoned, but was saved by his daughter together with a young man. They went to Mr. Yang’s boat and found the authentic woodcarving but were poisoned by an old man on the boat. It turned out that the thief was the county magistrate, who wanted to sell the woodcarving to foreigners. After a big fight, Liu with his daughter and the young man eventually killed the magistrate and Mr. Yang and saved the treasure.

Fan Zhongyan’s (AD. 989-1052, Song Dynasty) ‘Travel Notes on Yueyang Building’ is a very well-known prose and has a unique place in Chinese literature. Fan’s famous sentence in the prose, “one should be the first in his/her country to worry about state affairs, and the last to enjoy oneself” is widely quoted and has become the motto for many Chinese people.

The film well combines different genres such as suspense, martial arts and melodrama. The Pearl River Film Studio, based in Guangzhou, produced quite some commercially successful films and this is just one example. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)

results.title: 60 cycles
results.creator_credit: Jean-Claude Labrecque, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The 11th St. Laurent long-distance cycle race; with participants from thirteen countries; and fifteen hundred miles of Quebec countryside to cover in twelve days. From a distance the cyclists are a moving colourful frieze against the picturesque landscape; closer, we see the taut faces and straining limbs of the competitors above the bright circles of their machines. (Awards: Moscow, London, Prague, New York, Cork)

results.title: A (Darren Almond)
results.brief_description:
Darren Almond’s film and video works create a tension between stillness and movement. The experience of place takes on a strong resonance in Almond’s minimalist but emotionally charged settings, which explore space, time and human subjectivity.

As an elemental ‘landscape simply made up of air, liquid and gas in different states’, Antarctica is a location that has long fascinated Almond. In early 2002, the artist was invited by Mission Antarctica to crew for a month around the Antarctic Peninsula. A is his response to that journey, in which Antarctica represents ‘the axis of time and space, the axis of everything’.

Almond’s haunting film envelopes the viewer in an abstract world, devoid of human presence. Skimming the crystalline surfaces of the ice islands, A slowly reveals delicate variations in the landscape as ice meets water and sky. The near-silence of Antarctica is matched with a dreamy score and the sampling of real sounds-cracks and rips in the ice-that Almond recorded on his journey. The visual and aural experience of A is as much an interior, psychological journey as an exterior one to the ‘end’ of the earth.

(SW 30.03.05)
